title: AIO Camera Case for VM275T & CM275T

description.text:
This is a protective camera case which can be used to protect almost any of the small all-in-one (AIO) camera/VTX units such as the VM275T and its variants. The camera case uses 2mm bolts to attach to the mounting plate/bracket.

While designed to be printed using rigid filaments, the protective camera "pod" also works great when printed in flexible filaments such as TPU/Ninjaflex. The mounting plate/bracket however needs to be printed using rigid filaments to allow the 2mm bolts something to "bite" into.

The "CAM_CASE_COMP_108_MOUNT" allows this case to be used to mount an AIO camera on the Comp108 micro quad frame. The Comp 108 design can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2264856

A simple door lock to keep the kids out of the closet.  Easy to modify SLDPRT file for different thickness doors.   Prevents the door from opening when in the center section, slide it over to open.  Simple and effective!

In a Makerbot or anything similar print the file with the added ledge flat side down with supports. There will be a little .4mm support added on top of the long square bricks you can then break off the handle.
Makerware fails to make support on this geometry. I have not tested ReplicatorG

  • On a Stratasys machine, just print the simple file flat side down.

    • I made the part 1" Longer and 1" Larger so it does not pop off on certain doors. You will still need to modify this for your particular size door.

comments.text: Added a Makerbot configuration in the SLDPRT and a .thing file.  Prints fine on a Stratasys 3D printer, but will not on a Makerbot without added support under the handle.

title: Tablet bracket for DJI Mavic Pro (above sticks)

description.text:
The bracket for the DJI Mavic Pro moves the tablet mount up above the sticks similar to the Phantom series controllers. It is a much more comfortable, ergonomic setup. This bracket locks into the phone grip arms on the controller. There is a hole for the USB cable to pass through. You can angle the tablet grip down so it contacts the top of the controller. This pulls the bracket up tight to the back of the controller so it doesn't flop around loose.
I am using this bracket with the cheap tablet grip clone from banggood. I assume the DJI-brand bracket will work too, but I don't have one to test so I'm not sure. Here is a link to the cheap clone on banggood:

https://www.banggood.com/Tablet-Bracket-Holder-Mount-For-DJI-Phantom-34-Inspire-1-Flysky-FS-i6S-Transmitter-p-1079859.html

description.text:
The USB socket on the Melzi Controller Board can get quite a bit of stress. After having to resolder it, I designed this clamp to take some of the strain.

The design uses an M3 8mm Cap screw, an M3 20mm cap screw, one M3 washer and two M3 nuts. If you've only got screws a bit longer, it doesn't matter.

It simply screws on to the mounting hole on the corner of the board.

Please note: This clamp blocks the micro SD card in its slot - it's a feature,not a bug. I hardly ever use the card. If you swap it regularly though, this design is probably not for you!

author: The_Langst247

description.text:
All the STLs required to print an ecksbot.  
The ecksbot design is a sturdier and sleeker derivative of the Prusa 2 built on EckerTech innovations and putting a little more Sells Mendel back into the mix, making it a true and evolutionary RepRap.  
We do not claim this as our own new design but rather another small step in the evolution of the RepRap hobby printer. It is designed around the concepts and efforts of the RepRap core team and should be considered as an extension of the project.  
We would like to thank the RepRap core team for inspiring not just us but the entire RepRap community to design, redesign, innovate and think outside the box.  Without the core team none of this would be possible.  
Keeping with RepRap tradition the ecksbot is released on the GPL license making this a true RepRap 3D printer.  
For more information on how we improved the ecksbot design over the Prusa 2 design please visit, blog.eckertech.com  
UPDATE:  Added ETC_c-end-idler2-adjuster, NewBearingHousingInner and NewBearingHousingOuter.  The new x end has a hole to add a bolt for easy z height adjustments.  The new bearing housing requires only acetone for adhesion and fits together better than the old version.

To Build the ecksbot you'll need print the listed files with the quantities listed here http://forum.eckertech.com/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=118 The complete BOM including electrical and mechanical parts can be found here: http://forum.eckertech.com/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=118 We also have a complete build manual with step by step instructions for assembling your ecksbot that can be found here: http://forum.eckertech.com/viewforum.php?f=4&sid=0dee0e469d19ddeee94ae8ecdd2140e8 Source files for Solidworks and Step as well as STL's are available on github here:
https://github.com/eckertech/Ecksbot Eckertech Inc. sells both DIY kits and fully assembled printers here:
http://www.eckertech.com/ecksbot/ For a youtube video of the ecksbot please visit:
http://youtu.be/b88uoyQ6-W8 Checkout this video of an ecksbot printing a dragon:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kUaVnFvd5UI

comments.text: So after much fiddling, I've come to this conclusion. The Eckstruder isn't compatible with deep cut hobbed bolt, the Arcol Hyenas which are cut down to a 6mm dia cannot be made to work. Shallow cut bolts are OK.
comments.author: Bracken

comments.text: Our hobbed bolt, which we have been using for the past four years and is widely considered the best hobbed bolt on the market, works just fine. So, I would say the Arcol Hyenas is not compatible with the eckstruder.  We actually didn't anticipate anyone using such a deeply cut hobbed bolt.

comments.text: I'm currently trying to build one of these and right now I'm stuck on the X carriage using a Nema 17 motor (48 mm length) that seems to be too large for the X carriage since it is right in the path of the belt.  I know this is a derivation from the other repraps and it seems to use the same wades extruder, but do you have any specs on what the size of that extruder stepper motor should be?  Do you know of any mods to allow for bigger stepper motors on the extruder?  If there is nothing out there I will probably attempt to make my own version for it
comments.author: cade007

comments.text: Yikes! We didn't anticipate anyone using a motor that big for the extruder. The stepper motor we use is a 63 oz-in, 1.5amp, 1.8 degree/step Nema 17 (37mm in length).  This motor provides more than enough power to extrude (it's actually a bigger motor than required)
comments.author: cade007

comments.text: Thanks, that is very helpful!  I'll just find another stepper motor  with those specs rather than trying to mod for the bigger motor since as you mentioned the 63 oz-in is more than enough power.  Can't wait to see this thing in action, I like the design!

description.text:
Hi!

This is a Heart shaped puzzle using Tetris pieces.

Every piece is a small building generated using a remix of my Futuristic Cities and Sci-fi Cities algorithms in OpenSCAD.

The files:
heart-pieces.zip : full set of the 24 STLs needed for completing the puzzle.
frame.zip: STL's for the frame. (frame.stl->Full frame and frame1/2/3/4.stl for the splitted frame if the full frame doesn't fit in your printer bed)

frame/frame-split.123ddx :123DDesing files for the frame. Feel free to modify and made your own frame.

Unzipped STL's : a full set of pieces generated using Customizer

You can use the Customizer for generating new random full sets of pieces (one piece for every possible shape including 1-tile,2-tiles and 3-tiles shapes)
In the Customizer you can set the tile size (In examples i've used a size of 20mms) and generate sets of pieces of any size.

The puzzle it's not very difficult to solve but is quite changelling. There's many possible solutions, just like the Pentominos but using 4-tiles pieces.

Hope you enjoy it
Have fun!

Printer:

ANET E10 / Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No special settings, easy print. It takes around 30-60 mins per piece and 90-120 mins for printing the frame.

For the 4 pieces of frame i've designed the connecors with high tolerance to avoid problems fitting the frame.

author: wisar

description.text:
This is a box to make your smoke stopper look good. The box can be printed with whatever type of plastic you prefer. I used PETG and it worked well. The Lid must be printed in a translucent plastic. XT60 connectors won't stay in place via friction alone. They will have to be glued (I used superglue beneath the connectors + hot glue on top).

The lid has spots for two switches:
1 on/off switch (plug in your battery without necessarily powering your electronics)
1 hi/low switch (between high/low on the lightbulb. Allows you to change the max current you let through to the electronics)

Other parts you will need:
XT60 (male) connectors(x2):
https://www.amazon.com/LingSY-Female-Bullet-Connectors-Battery/dp/B06XV8L8L8/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?s=toys-and-games&ie=UTF8&qid=1510243304&sr=1-1-spons&keywords=male+xt60&psc=1
On/off rocker switches(x2):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B011U1NU90/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Light bulb fixture(x1):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0087D9A44/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Light Bulb(x1): https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008DX2WFW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Electrical diagram forthcoming...
Pictures forthcoming...

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200

Infill:

25%

Notes:

-Box, bracket, and lid printed in PETG.
-ABS should work with no modification.
-LID MUST BE PRINTED WITH A TRANSLUCENT PLASTIC!!
-PLA might have to be sized up by 1-2%.
-The XT-60 connectors are a tight fit with PETG.
-Electrical Hazard sign printed in TPU to make it easy to fit into the lid.

This was needed as a frame for the legs of a remix of Pongo's 3piece stool seat (seat pieces can be found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2022200)

The frame is made to be printed 3 times and have the individual pieces interlock with each other. This will keep the legs from splaying too far apart when you sit on the stool. I found that the frame would slide down the legs (narrowing the base) so it may need to have a rubber band to keep the frame at one level on each leg. No gluing is needed.

This was printed using a Monoprice Maker III, PLA, .3mm layer thickness, bed temp 65, hot end temp 225, fan speed 75%, 20% infill (printing this on it's side allowed for enough strength when connected with each other), using a skirt to prime the extruder.
All other settings were defaulted to Cura's normal settings.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eaHhfUIhY3b

author: Cingle

description.text: This is for mounting a J-head to a Wade's Extruder. The J-Head in the Photo is the Mk. V-b, but Any J-head will fit because it is Parametric. It Measures 70x25x8mm, so it shouldn't get in the way of your extruder gears.

Updated: I added a filling.scad and .stl, it is for the gap between the Wade's Extruder and the Hotend. This keeps the filament from getting caught up.
The Mounting Plate now has Nut Traps so you can use M3 x 25, and not have any screw left on the other side. Update 2:
I added another STL file with a wireholder attached to the clamp, this is for holding the wires that run from the Hotend.
I kept the STL file that doesn't have that.
I also changed the OpenSCAD file, with the wireholder added. If you don't want it, just change the "wireholder=true;" to wireholder=false;" The STL is set up for M3 Nuts and Screws, If you want to change this, use the Variables in the .Scad File, But remember to change the thickness of the overall Plate accordingly.

description.text:
A model to demonstrate the gravity-defying power of osmosis.  
It costs around $15 to make (if you have access to a laser cutter).

1) Cut two of each part (stand and clamp)
2) Cut the U-Tube in half. The one I used was the Eshopps AEO19005 U-Tube
3) Using acrylic glue, glue the U-tube into the hole. Some heat forming may be necessary
4) Cut a strip of dialysis tube and clamp it in place with four 16mm M3 screws
5) Fill each side with solutions of differing solute concentrations

author: mrice

title: Anycubic i3 Mega Silent Parts Cooling Fan Bracket

description.text:
If you changed to Trinamic 2208 stepper motor driver and replaced the all noisy fans of Anycubic i3 Mega, only thing you can hear is the blower fan noise because nobody makes a quiet blower.
This upgrade will enable you to replace it with a silent Noctua or Ainex 40x10mm axial fan and cut down the noise to "zero" and makes your printer "ultra silent".
Included duct is a short design, so the axial fan works perfectly.

  • Hotend must be rotated 45 degree to clear the electrical wires.
  • Only parts-fan-bracket must be printed with a support enabled.
  • Awesome Trinamc 2208 (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FvW93yCbqFE)

Available here (5 pieces required with heatsink):

  • https://www.digikey.com/products/en?keywords=1460-1201-ND
  • https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/assmann-wsw-components/V2017B/AE10837-ND/3511410
  • https://e3d-online.com/tmc2208
  • http://www.watterott.com/index.php?page=product&info=5089

Installation reference (old tmc2100 as example (be sure to use new tmc2208) ):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PVF-PNP_F40

Note:
To install a 20mm tall fan instead of a 10mm fan, the space for the wiring becomes tight. In that case, change the hotend connector to the "90 degree type", available at
(https://www.pololu.com/product/2718) Or (https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/jst-sales-america-inc/S2B-XH-A-LF-SN/455-2257-ND/1651055)
Target: (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1DrC_pccUtPYGE0xng8ZjoZMXmAfy6XhA/view?usp=sharing)

comments.author: davibe

comments.text:
That's because you received the newest SKU#"mega04" stock of i3 Mega.
It uses Tri-gorila Pro main board with same old on-board A4988 stepper motor drivers (not replaceable).
It shouldn't be called "Pro" because the old driver is not upgradable.
If possible, you need to exchange it to SKU#"mega03" stock which has a standard Tri-gorila board.
Changing the main board alone doesn't work because the connection type of TFT display is different, SD card reader is separate unit and connector conversion board is used.
https://imgur.com/gallery/9HPeh

50% infill rate gives good strength for print.

comments.text:
There's nothing to configure for 2208 because the default setting works fine.
Default reading should be about 1.2 volts. Only the extruder motor works better with 1.4V to give it a little more power.

comments.author: Domi1988

comments.text:
Yes, it works even if less than 5 pieces. It's necessary to turn the motor cable connector upside down because
the pin arrangement of all TMC driver is the opposite of the factory driver.
As for 2208, the default 1.2 volts reference voltage of the driver works fine so there's nothing to configure.
Price is almost same between German and China made 2208 module .
You cannot go wrong with German made module because it's the original.
I don't know if China copy requires extra configuration.

description.text:
I created this to isolate my 3D printer from the table to reduce vibration (requires at least 4 - one for each corner), but it is also just fun to play with. The number of magnets determine how much weight can be supported by the floating top.

There is no stable arrangement of permanent magnets that will float without supports (See Earnshaw's Theorem : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earnshaw%27s_theorem), so this uses a holder and top and then either a rubber band or a weighted object to hold it in place.

The model uses #07046 neodymium magnets (https://www.amazon.com/Master-Magnetics-Super-Magnets-Mfg-07046/dp/B01MCTW9F2).

The Inventor file is attached if you want to customize the holder height or use a different magnet size.

QB-BD Two Up

Rafts:

No

No

Infill:

100%

print_settings.Notes:: I've printed this model as small as 120mm but lowed the speed to 30mm/sec and dropped the temperature to 190C. I used a brim of 8mm on an unheated glass bed with a swipe of a glue stick. I doubled the wall thickness to 1.6mm and dropped the infill to 4% but I've gotten away with even less when I used the gradual infill at 5 in Cura. Supports are a must with all the overhangs!

description.text:
I took a previous scan of a copy of a bronze cast on request by Bartholdi. The original bronze was cast by the French foundry Thiebaut-freres in the late 19th century. The original stood about 21 inches in height.

I altered it slightly to more closely reflect the final design of the Statue of Liberty in New York. I altered the rays to more closely align with those in New York. I rotated the flame to approximately the same angle as well.

Otherwise I largely left the remainder of the scan as-is.

The details are somewhat lacking and could use touch ups by anyone in Blender, Zbrush, etc. The most important details that have been lost are the facial feature, the fingers, the toes, the date on the tablet, the wavy pattern of the coiffure and the balustrade on the torch. Perhaps the broken shackles could use some clarity as well.

It will still look good as-is but would be a great project for someone to clean up. The size of this model is 480mm. No particular reason for that size but you can easily resize it in Meshmixer, Netfabb, etc.

I hope you enjoy this model. If you do work on it, please share your work with me as I'd love to see it.

Monoprice Select Mini V1

Notes:

I've printed this model as small as 120mm but lowed the speed to 30mm/sec and dropped the temperature to 190C. I used a brim of 8mm on an unheated glass bed with a swipe of a glue stick. I doubled the wall thickness to 1.6mm and dropped the infill to 4% but I've gotten away with even less when I used the gradual infill at 5 in Cura. Supports are a must with all the overhangs!
I created this slightly cleaned up and altered model from an older scan. I also decimated the model to shrink the file size but at the cost of the finest details.

description.text:
I'm using this magnetic holders since 2 years and they're doing great job for me. Fast atachement to the carriage, fast replacement with other fans (more silent or more powerfull). An the main reason - fast access to hotend.

As you can see - I've designed small holder that fits place in Robo R1 carriage an it's fastened with a single screw. This holder contains two 6x6 round neodyme magnets that are pushed to the holder's holes with some unstripped wire. This wire is soldered to right wires in the printer (PWM fan output on RAMPS board - same place as factory fan)

Fans (40x40mm) are put to it's places in fan holder. It's wires are connected in the same way as holder's, to the magnets pushed into holes. Some glue can be used, but it's not necessary if the printout is tight. Printed pins that fits fan holes can be treated with tip of soldering iron and melted to keep fan in place.

Funny thing.. I wanted Robo 3D team to see those designs before others, but it seems.. they were not interesed in that...
So, now I want to share this idea for free with the world.

Those models are suitable for E3D v5 head - longer that factory one. Better check if it will fits you before print.

That's all folks!
Happy printing, happy using.

https://youtu.be/fiJ-MZ5ckRg

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Bigger fan holder and fan connector can be printed without support. Simplified fan holder need support only from building platform.
Those parts on pictures are printed in PET.

author: Gregorban

description.text:
Roman Arcs are nice in the sence that they do not requiere clue (or concrete) to keep em together.
The top stone (also called key stone, I guess) and further weight on it keeps everything together. 
To assemble the arc one needs a scafolding to lay the curved stones on before the key stone is inserted.
One problem so, is that lateral forces need to be accomodated carefully. Thats why the two collums are wedged into the base plate: to keep them from toppling over.

3D print.
Assemble.
Tell me about it.
(Stl's repaired with netfabb Studio Basic 4.9)

I am always 3D printing and like to prep my next peace of glass before
the current project is finished. However I have found by just laying my
glass flat it will collect dust, crumbs or other junk on top of my fresh tape and will force me to use alcohol or other products to clean it before I can print. I have found by standing them up straight solves
my problems. I drew this up in (inch) not (mm) so you may have to change your config settings to bring this into your software in inch.
the grip is for .090 to .100 thick glass

description.text: Remixed with the latticework 2x the nozzle diameter as my printer had trouble printing such fine lines

Instructions

These instructions below are especially for Ultimaker2 printer and Cura software. Please adjust any parameter as needed if you are using other software.

  1. Use 'normal' quality. Or if you're an expert, consider using the settings provided below.

  2. Print the top board ???-Sorter-topboard.stl.
    Cura expert settings:

    • Layer height = 0.1mm,
    • Shell thickness = 2.4mm,
    • Bottom/top thickness = 1.5mm.
    • Print!

  3. Print the base box ???-Sorter-box.stl.
    Cura expert settings:

    • Layer height = 0.1mm,
    • Shell thickness = Bottom/top thickness = 1.2mm.
    • Tune retraction settings at the printer:
    • Retraction length = 3mm.
    • Print!

  4. Print the tubes ???-Sorter-tubes.stl.

    • Same settings as step 3.
  5. Put them together. Done!

author: Flynoceros

description.text: My girlfriend's a realtor and she wanted a house shaped necklace pendant. I modelled this up in AutoDesk Inventor and it turned out decently. The photo is full scale, .5, .75, and .85 scale versions. I painted a couple, but I'm not much of a painter!

Printed with 30% infill because it happened to be set there. Printrbot simple did pretty good work. I think they layers look like roof tiles and siding so I kept them. I did paint with Tamiya paint (just stuff I had from a model motorcycle). X-18 for the chimney, X-19 for the roof, X-12 for the ring, X-7 for the door, and X-13 for the windows.

print_settings.Notes:: The mounting bracket need to be printed normal and mirrored in the X axis.

description.text:
This is an enclosure to hold a Duet WiFi and Duex expansion board back to back. Cooling air is directed between the two boards. A feed through slot is provided for the power connection and the data cable.

Print the two sides of the box and join them together using M3 screws and nuts. I recommend also gluing the parts together.

There are two versions of the door. One has a pattern cut through it just for appearance. The other has no pattern - it can be used as is or you can cut you own pattern in it.

The mounting bracket needs to be printed twice. Once normal and once mirrored.

As this is a work in progress it may be updated from time to time.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The mounting bracket need to be printed normal and mirrored in the X axis.

description.text:
hello,

i designed this stand to put on my rc table, but can be used on many different level's

it has place for tools, scissors, hobby knife, an area for small parts.

i designed it for my iphone 5s. it has room for the charging cable, and a stand so it keeps in place.

on the under-side there is a area where you can wind the rest of the cable that you don't use, and a gap where you can come out with your cable.

also you will see a tunnel system that gets more sound out of your phone. so you use less energy off your phone.

if you are interested, but have a different phone, i can design one specially for you. if you like it, but have a different setup in mind, i can design it for you. please feel free to contact me.

UNTESTED AS OF NOV. 9/17

Add a bit of mystery to your next Gift Card gift.  Simply insert a Gift Card inside this box during printing and once complete, the card is encased in a thin shell.  Leave it to the recipient to figure out how to get the card out.  This is intended to be a single use print, with opening involving destroying it in some way.

The inside of the vault is hollow, with 1mm sides all around, and is large enough to easily accommodate a standard gift card (possibly two) . The purpose of the side tower is to have a place to pause the print that is offset enough to get the extruder out of the way of the vault.
Print with the vault standing upright, with a long edge on the printbed. At approximately 90% completion, pause the print while the extruder is over the side tower. Insert the gift card and then complete the print to seal in the card.
Vaults with "Question marks", "Happy Birthday", and "Merry Christmas" are provided. Also included is a blank vault awaiting personalization.
Versions without the 'tower' are provided in case you have a better way to pause the print when inserting the card.

These products are typically made from cold rolled carbon steel sheet with a zinc-plated or chromated bright surface finish. The term derives from the original specifications published by Deutsches Institut für Normung (DIN) in Germany, which have since been adopted as European (EN) and international (IEC) standards.[1]

title: Saitek X52 Pro Throttle and Joystick VESA Monitor Arm Adapters

description.text:
Adapters to securely attach a Saitek X52 Pro HOTAS to VESA standard mounting arms. Includes push fasteners to connect the adapter plate to the VESA mount and twist connecters to fasten the controllers to the adapter plates. You may need to scale the push clips lengthwise on the X-axis to accommodate the thickness of your VESA mount.

I built a desk from a slab of maple and 1 ¼” copper pipe and fittings… the pipe turned out to be a perfect fit for a monitor arm I found on Amazon and repurposed as a swinging mount for my X52 Pro: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0052ATODM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Not a direct remix since I started from scratch on the mounting plates, but I took inspiration from @GMBridge and repackaged his push and twist clips for my thing.

title: E3D v6 hot end mount for Anycubic Linear Plus

description.text:
I was having trouble finding an effector mount for my new E3D v6 hot end on my Anycubic Linear Plus delta printer. The designs I found either didn't fit the hot end when printed (on a calibrated printer) or I just didn't like the design (over complicated/bulky etc).

So I started taking measurements and attempted to design one myself. I tried to keep it as simple and light as possible while still performing all the functions I required (part cooling fan, mount for Z level sensor and waste as little Z height as possible, printable with as little infill as possible). Overall I'm pretty happy with how it came out.

Being the most complicated thing I've designed yet I opted to mount the top of the cold end to the plate to keep things simple at the cost of some Z height. When I revisit the design at a later date I will be trying to have as much of the hot end above the effector plane as possible, this will also help to reduce any tilt from the delta rods.

  • All the screw holes are designed to fit M3 screws and nuts.
  • The spacing between the delta rods is 52.2mm (measured distance on my printer). If you need a larger spacing you could use (or print) some washers. If you need a smaller spacing I have added the .rsdoc file that you can edit. There is also the .stl for a plain effector that only mounts the hot end, you could drill your own holes for other attachments.
  • The fan mount holds a 40x40x10 fan with the standard hole placement. This also uses M3 holes and mounts snugly.
  • The Z level sensor mount fits a sensor with a 18mm diameter thread. Secure the sensor using nuts either side of the sensor.

I would recommend securing the delta rod screws with nuts on the other side of the effector mounts. Currently I have just secured my screws with a small amount of glue as I haven't got long enough screws yet (a M3x25 might do the job).

Printer:

Anycubic Linear Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The effector plate and hot end clamps can be printed without support but you will probably need supports to print the part cooling fan shroud.

You will need to print:
1x Effector plate v2
2x Cold end clamp
1x Part cooler

It's fairly intuitive how they fit together and I have uploaded a few images for reference.
Designed in DesignSpark Mechanical 2.0

title: Anet A8 single motor Z axis drive

description.text:
This is a way to sync the Z-axis drive using a single motor.

Printed parts:

  • plateL.stl - top left plate, the motor and idler are mounted here
  • plateR.stl - top right plate, essentially a mirror image of the left plate, but without the motor and pulley.
  • rod_plug.stl (print 2) - replaces the original guiding rod plugs on top plates
  • rod_holder.stl (print 2) - holds the guiding rods from below, since the motors aren't there anymore
  • tube_guard.stl (optional) - keeps my bowden tube from interfering with the timing belt

If you prefer the motor on the right, you can print mirror images of the plateL.stl and plateR.stl.

Hardware needed:

  • use the original 4 M3 screws and nuts to mount the top plates
  • 976mm 488 teeth GT2 (6mm) closed belt (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Hot-sales-GT2-timing-belt-976-2GT-6-length-976mm-width-6mm-teeth-488-for-3D/32299312364.html)
  • GT2 18 teeth pulley 5mm bore - mounted on the motor (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3d-printer-2GT-GT2-Timing-Pulley-18-teeth-Alumium-Bore-5mm-for-GT2-Belt-Width-6mm/32835852375.html)
  • 2x flange bearings 8mm bore (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/8mm-Bearing-Zinc-Alloy-Miniature-Bearing-Pedestal-KFL08-Flange-Pillow-Block-Bearing-diy-cnc-parts/32773248332.html)
  • 2x GT2 36teeth timing pulleys with 8mm bore (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3d-printer-pulley-aluminum-timing-pulley-2GT-36teeth-bore-5mm-6mm-6-35mm-8mm-10mm-pulley/32658350983.html)
  • 1x idler pulley for GT2, 5mm bore - (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Timing-Gear-Pulley-Without-tooth-Idle-Pulley-synchronous-Round-5mm-For-GT2-Belt-Width-6MM-Power/32761426168.html)
  • M8 rod, length 349mm - needed to stiffen the frame, because the frame is too flimsy to withstand the timing belt tension
  • 4x M8 nuts and washers to fix the M8 rod
  • 4x M5 25mm screws and nuts and washers - to fix the flange bearings
  • 1x M5 40mm screw and 2x M5 nuts and a washer - to mount the pulley idler
  • 2x M3 20mm screws and nuts for the top rod plugs
  • 4x M3 15mm screws and nuts to mount the bottom rod holders
  • 4x M3 12mm screws and washers for motor mounting

The mounting holes for the flange bearings are a bit oversized so you can keep the leadscrews and the guiding rods parallel. The way I did it:

  1. Mount the flange bearing without tightening the mounting screws
  2. fix the leadscrews in the bearings
  3. bring the X-axis assembly (the one that rides on the leadscrews and rods) all the way up (maximal expected Z height)
  4. ensure that the leadscrews are parallel to the guiding rods (I eyeballed it, by keeping the bottom of the leadscrews above the Z motor axes, which were yet unmounted at this stage).
  5. tighten the flange bearing mounting screws

Don't forget to change the steps/mm parameter for the z axis (from the original 400 to 800)

Hope I included everything here. If you find anything missing, please comment and I'll answer/update.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

title: GM pump assembly to XJ tank - adapter ring

description.text:
This is for installing a GM truck (All vortec) fuel pump assembly into a Jeep XJ fuel tank (late model plastic tank). Use this for all my LS swaps.

After screwing with tons of aftermarket pumps, expensive filter regulators and fittings, and having nothing but problems, I gave up and just stuck a stock GM truck pump and assembly into the XJ fuel tank. Works mint.

For those doing LS swaps, this is by far the easiest and probably best solution. You've already got the GM pump and can from the donor right? Why waste money and time with aftermarket parts of questionable quality?

Instructions:

  1. Print adapter ring out of something tough and fuel safe. PETG should be fine. I generally shoot for 3 perimeters, 40% infill, just because I want this thing to be as strong as a full potato.
  2. Remove the XJ pump assembly and throw it away where it won't hurt anyone ever again.
  3. Using both the GM and XJ rubber gaskets, assemble the adapter onto the GM pump assembly. It's a very snug fit. Should go on fine with a little spit (or grease if you've got it). Make sure to put the GM lock ring between the top of the adapter and the XJ tank locking ring.
  4. Remove the GM fuel sending arm if you're not using it.
  5. Stick the assembly into the tank and push down until the assembly bottoms out. Measure the gap between the mating surface of the ring to the top of the tank (where you'll thread things on). You're measuring how much of the pump can assembly legs you want to chop off here.
  6. Disassemble everything, chop off the legs to the correct length, reassemble and then re-flare the ends of the legs (regular flaring tool will do just fine).
  7. Drop it in and run some cheap nylon lines with 3/8 and 5/16 quick connect fittings. You can probably even re-use the lines that came with the donor truck. Stick a cheap filter in-line somewhere.

Going this route costs less than $50, and you get to use an OEM pump that you already know works for your application.

Pro-tip: If you're throwing an LS in anything, find a way to finagle an XJ tank in. They're an awesome tank, indestructible, cheap, easy to find, and they fit almost anywhere. I'm running this setup in my LS swapped, bobbed 95 4runner truggy on Land Cruiser BJ/FJ60 axles :). The GM tank is too big to fit anywhere, the Toyota tank is crappy steel and sits well below the frame. XJ tank fits very nicely just behind the rear axle. You can land on these tanks and they just bend and survive.

Printer:

Bastard FT5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 is more than adequate

Infill:

20-50%

Notes:

Print in something fuel safe guys. PETG SHOULD be fuel safe. I've been using it in my tank for about a month with no signs of degradation.

description.text:
This cord manager is meant for shorter, thinner cords, like those of headphones or lightning cables. This is a somewhat compact design that hides the cord while recommended to be carried in a bag, since it is not comfortable holding in pocket.

After many sample prototypes for this design, I have finally come to the conclusion of using a cylinder, divided into two parts: one a hollow cylinder for the cable to be put in, and the other a cap to keep it closed. Past designs may have involved pegs to hold it together which were not successful, rather than just one big extrusion from the cylinder. This larger extrusion makes it easier to design, print, and use. I later decided to change the piece that now is the cap from an identical second half, but with an indent instead of an extrusion, to the cap it is now. I did this because it saves filament, and I didn’t wrap the sides of the cap all the way around because I found that I liked the aesthetic appeal more than if I did.

The manager is approximately 2.7 cm tall, with an outer radius of 3 cm, and an inner diameter of 2 cm.
My design of this cord manager, I find, does an effective job of keeping my cord in place, where I may find it, and hides it from sight to it appears neat.

description.text:
A compact case for a classic heat bed power expansion module. A series of holes allows air flow for the MOSFET. The cutouts for the cables are designed so that the case can be removed without unplugging the cables. The 4 screws for the cables can be accessed while the case is mounted. Included is also a spacer for the PCB that can also be used as a drilling template.
The holes for the mounting screws are 2.8mm in diameter for M3 screws, so no additional nuts are needed.

I haven't printed this yet, and I'm not sure it'll be useful to do so, but I figured I may as well upload everything I design to here in case I need it later. I will be building these out of 2x2 lumber (1.5x1.5) and 1/2" plywood or OSB, but I made the model in 1:25.4 scale by simply not changing the default setting from mm to in :)

Shelves final dimensions will be 5' tall, 4' wide, and 21" deep (including verticals. actual shelves are 18" deep)

edit: I printed it now, and I think the 1:25.4 scale is possibly too small to print at. 0.5mm thick shelves aren't very strong, so I damaged one of the shelves a little bit while freeing it from the support material. I don't actually have a use for tiny shelves besides "look, I printed it", so I won't be printing another copy. When I get to the workshop (hopefully this weekend) to build the real thing, I'll post that as a made one :)

description.text: This a lesson on making a basic phone stand.

Creating basic-phone-holder1
By Glenn Mossy Here is all the parts we are going to use to assemble the phone holder: And is the final result:
  • Two “Box” Solid rectangles, make them purple, w 8 x d 50 x h 8.

  • You can place them as follows and group them together.

  • Get a “Wedge”, make it blue, w 68 x d 32.56 x h 12. Place at the end of the purple rectangles, and group.

  • Two “Pyramids” make them yellow, and 6 x 20 x 14, Place at the end of the purple rectangles on top.

  • Get a One “Box”, make it red, make a standing angle frame W 6.30 x l 68 x h 61.70.

  • Place at a 22.5 deg slant against the purple legs, rest against the workplane.

  • {Total size with a horizontal workplane after rotation of 22.5 degrees should be 68 x 25.90 x h 59.41}

  • Use the Align function to line up the parts, with the legs.

  • Align the Red Frame and Blue Wedge so that you will have a shelf to place your phone on it, and you will cut a divit for the phone. Use a ruler.

  • Place a “cylinder” hole 11 x 10 x 72 in the cradle base, placing the center of the cylinder at 12mm high into the “Wedge” and group together. You will need to use a vertical workplane on to the wedge and a ruler to get the 12mm height into the blue wedge.

  • Group the parts together.

  • Place a “box” hole to make a square hole D 50.13 x w 52.09 x h 53, inside the standing angle frame.

  • Center Align the hole inside the square frame.

  • Do a group of everything together so far, so that the box hole cuts a square hole into the standing angle frame.

  • Drop a workplane onto the red, standing angle frame.

  • Get two “MetaFillets” l 20 x h 20 x d 4 and place each on opposite sides of the standing square frame.

  • Place the metafillets inside the standing square frame.

  • Using a workplane on the frame. Add a “Gear” on to the workplane and size at d 22.9 x w 54 x h 51.91.

  • Use a new workplane on the frame to adjust the gear with the vertical arrow tip. Move the “Gear” to the inside of the standing angle frame. Make sure the gear tips are connected to the inside of the standing frame.

  • Create a “cylinder” hole for the gear sized 25 x 25 x h 20. Use this to cut a hole in the center of the gear. Remember to keep the workplane on the standing frame.

  • Use the vertical arrow to place the hole inside the gear.

  • Group together to cut the hole into the gear.

  • Reset the horizontal workplane and you are done and ready to export to an stl file!
• Tinkercad
1 hour

author: Macaroni_12

description.text: Use this collection of shapes and clips to make arbitrary objects that flex and drape like cloth. Bags, ties, belts for pants, clothes?! Plan your shape, print hexes & clips, and hand assemble. I made a hand-bag. Expand the second image to full-size to see a ruler for scale. See my hex-tie design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:256914) for a smaller hex pattern plus neck strap based on the same hex and clip principle.

First, plan your shape.  Next, print the hexes and clips and then hand assemble your object.  Be warned that hand assembly takes significant time!  
Designed for .2 or .4mm layers.  I use .4mm because its faster and the bed-down surface looks the same regardless.  Clips are easiest to assemble when printed in ABS, or use PLA for a stiffer/stronger clip.  In either case, print the clips sideways (as per the STL) to maximize flexibility.  
To get the clips on, slide them over the flat part of the hex and push them sideways over the hub.  With some practice you can snap them on in less than a second.  This works better than trying to force them straight over the hub.  
The hand-bag design pictured above uses 28 half hexes, 182 hexes, and 2 "hex flakes" for the sides.  Most of the bag is a tube of about 14 rows of 14 hexes (minus the hex flakes, which are equivalent to 7 hexes each).  There are over 400 clips for the sides alone.  The bottom is 19 hexes and 10 half hexes, assembled, 2 hexes wide and ~13 hexes long.  Straps can be made with more hexes but I made mine with little triangles.   Note there are two kinds of half hexes, one with a clip on the long side, and one without.  The latter would be used as the outer edge (say, the top edge of a bag).

description.text:
In order to do gutters, I needed to create a new street style, as the fan cobble wasn't going to work real well for that. Because of that, we now get a new cobble style that is great for streets, but also particularly well suited for alleyways.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

For each street tile, print yourself one of street.* and a base of the same size (2x2, 2x4 or 4x4). The streets are in 25mm square basis (which matches Dwarven Forge). If you want that size, print without changes, and print one of the 25mm bases. If you instead want inch squares, scale the street tile on X and Y by 101.6% and print one of the inch bases. Finally, if you want wyloch style tiles (1.25" per square) scale the X and Y by 127%.

Other Street Tiles

You can find the rest of this set as it gets released, along with some other city street tiles that people from around thingiverse have been creating in the OpenForge 2 Streets Collection

Gearbest provided me with their Tronxy X5s printer. I've fixed the bowden problem and the printer is doing really well. Main observation I have from this print is that you should not print these tiles at .2 layer height, go for .1. With the Tronxy, .1 on these is really smooth.

I add:

  • CR10 registration
  • an angle of 45 on the part where the LED strip is glued so as not to have a reflection in the mirror
  • a stop to hold the bar in the open position
  • A hole in the width of the LED strip to avoid having to weld

For editing, watch the designer's video: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2492135

For when the standard size is just not enough!  
Just a bigger hopper for a vertically mounted Filastruder.  
I also extended the chute to give the required clearance. It comes in two versions, look to see which one you need. I need the short version for my Filastruder no. 787. (Still waiting for the replacements of defective parts to be sent back)  
I have not yet printed this version, so as always, all feedback is welcome!
